Graphical abstract The oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) over PdRu solid solution nanoparticles was studied by the combined theoretical and experimental approaches. In this work, CO and O adsorptions on PdRu alloy surface models were theoretically investigated to understand the kinetics of CO oxidation reaction. It was found that CO adsorption on Pd atom in the PdRu alloy surfaces is weaker than on monometallic surfaces. From the experiment, reaction order of CO on the PdRu surface was observed to be smaller than that on Pd surface. While, the positive first order with respect to O2 obtained for both Pd and PdRu alloy surfaces. Catalytic reaction mechanism is discussed on the basis of both theoretical and experimental observations. Keywords CO oxidation PdRu nanoalloy Langmuir-Hinshelwood Kinetics Reactions order 1 Introduction Urban air quality deterioration caused by automotive exhaust emissions was noticed as early as the 1970s due to the increased use of vehicles. [1] Hydrocarbon (HC), CO and NOx are widely regarded as major harmful pollutants from the emissions. Since then, three-way-catalysts (TWCs) have been used in the automobile industry to simultaneously (i) oxidize CO to CO2; (ii) reduce NOx to N2 and (iii) combust unburnt hydrocarbons [2–7]. Normally, metallic Pt, Pd and Rh are the main active components of TWCs. For CO and hydrocarbon oxidation, Pt and Pd are utilized, while Rh is employed for NOx reduction. [8] However, Rh and Pt is limited in abundance and very expensive. Recently, Kusada et al. have successfully synthesized the PdxRu1-x solid solution alloy nanoparticles (SSNPs) even though the Pd and Ru are normally immiscible in bulk phase. [9] The structure of Pd0.5Ru0.5 SSNPs has been well defined experimentally by means of TEM, XRD and XPS. [9] The Pd0.5Ru0.5 SSNPs were reported to show an enhanced NOx reduction activity compared to Rh. [10] Additionally, both Pd and Ru are considerably cheaper than Rh and more affordable to be used as automobile catalyst. While Pd is excellent for CO oxidation, it is noted that the Pd is susceptible to the CO poisoning due to the well-known CO inhibition phenomenon [11–13]. Pd catalyst also shows inherently lower activity for NOx reduction due to the self-poisoning by hydrocarbon molecules. [7,14,15] In recent years, many efforts have been made towards improving the catalytic activity and the CO poisoning tolerance of Pd-based alloys. The bimetallic systems are interesting as it increase the catalysis’s complexity and expected to show higher catalytic performance [16]. For example, the PdAu alloy nanoparticles showed superior CO oxidation activity compared with Pd and Au systems [17]. Highly active PdAu alloy however strongly depends on the preparation method [18]. While PdCu showed the promising CO oxidation catalysis, the higher affinity towards oxygen by Cu led to the poisoning on the catalyst surface [19]. Similarly, Shan et al. and Shao et al. reported remarkable activity when alloying Pd with Ni [20] and Fe [21]. While those works are aiming at enhancing the catalytic activity of Pd by alloying, the work by Sato et al. 10 focused on the development of an inexpensive and highly active NOx reduction catalyst by alloying the immiscible combinations of Pd and Ru, which acts as pseudo-rhodium. Thus, it is interesting to explore the underlying mechanism behind those combination materials to suggest the possible factors that are responsible for high catalytic activity. In this work, we focused on the functionality of bimetallic PdRu system on CO oxidation. The CO and O adsorptions on PdRu surface were analyzed by using density functional theory (DFT) method and compared with Pd, Ru, and Rh surfaces. The reaction order on Pd, Ru, and PdRu was also analyzed by both DFT and experimental approaches. 2 Methods 2.1 Computational details In this study, DFT calculations were performed by using Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [22,23]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) under generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used as exchange and correlation functional [24]. Core electrons were treated by using a projector augmented wave (PAW) method [25,26]. Brillouin zone sampling of 7 × 7 × 1 (14 × 14 × 14 for bulk case) k-points was generated by the Monkhorst-Pack procedure [27] and cutoff energy of 400 eV in plane-wave basis sets was used. The convergence threshold for self-consistent field calculations was 10 × 10−5 eV/atom. The cell and atomic positions were optimized by a conjugate gradient method with tolerances of 10 × 10-4 eV/atom. First, the equilibrium lattice constants of four atoms unit cell of bulk Pd, Ru, and Rh and Pd0.5Ru0.5 systems were optimized. Table 1 summarizes the optimized lattice parameter of Pd, Ru, Rh and the Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy systems. The calculated results were compared with literatures [28–33]. For example, the lattice parameter of bulk Pd was 3.95 Å, in close agreement with the previously reported value of 3.94 Å. [28] Hence, it has been demonstrated that our calculation condition reproduces the previous DFT results of Pd, Ru and Rh bulk systems. The surface structures were modeled based on the supercell approach and were consisted of three atomic layers with four atoms in each layer. A vacuum layer of 11 Å was introduced in the supercell to avoid the interaction between the slabs. The 11 Å vacuum layer is sufficient to eliminate the interaction between periodic slabs in calculation as reported elsewhere [34]. The (111) and (0001) surface facets were considered as the most stable surfaces of cubic (fcc) and hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structures, respectively. Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloys were prepared by replacing two Ru atoms in each layer of Pd-fcc or Pd-hcp structure (totally six Ru atoms). The atomic arrangement of Pd and Ru in the top layer of the surface model was fixed. Pd and Ru atoms in second and bottom layers were arranged to have different configuration considering the symmetry, and as the results, 20 different configurations were prepared (Figure S1). Before the introduction of the adsorbents on the metal surface, atomic positions in surface model were optimized under the fixed cell size. Only the top and the second layers of surface model were relaxed, while the bottom layer was fixed. Then, the adsorbents were introduced to the optimized metal surface models. The initial adsorption sites considered were the high symmetry sites; i.e., top, bridge and 3-fold-hollow sites (Fig. 1 a). The atomic positions of adsorbate and 3-layers slab model were then optimized to obtain the most stable adsorption sites. In case of the Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy, 20 additional sites were investigated for each configuration; namely, top Pd, top Ru, bridge Pd-Pd, bridge PdRu, and bridge PdRu, 3-fold Pd2Ru and 3-fold PdRu2, as shown in Fig. 1b. The adsorption energy, Δ E a d s , was calculated as the difference between the total energy of the surface with adsorbed molecule and the sum of the total energies of the metal surface without adsorbate and the isolated adsorbate molecule by the following equation: (1) Δ E ads = ( E M + A − E M − E A ) where EM+A , EM and EA are the total energies of the surface with adsorbed molecule, the metal surface without adsorbate and the isolated adsorbate molecule obtained by DFT calculations, respectively. 2.2 Experimental details Infrared (IR) spectra of adsorbed CO were measured with a spectrometer (FT/IR-6600, JASCO, Japan) equipped with a mercury–cadmium–tellurium detector at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Samples (20 mg) were pressed into self-supporting disks (10 mm in diameter). Each disk was placed in a silica-glass cell equipped with CaF2 windows and was then connected to a closed gas-circulation system. The disk was pretreated with circulated H2 (5 kPa) that had been passed through a liquid nitrogen trap. The disk was heated from room temperature to 160 °C and then kept at that temperature for 0.5 h. After the reduction, the cell containing the disk was evacuated at the same temperature for 0.5 h to remove the H2. After this pretreatment, the disk was cooled to room temperature under a vacuum, CO (0.5 kPa) was supplied to the system. The IR spectrum of the sample at room temperature before N2 adsorption was used as the background, and difference spectra were obtained by subtracting the background spectra from the spectra of the samples containing adsorbed CO. The kinetics of CO oxidation reaction, then was investigated on Pd, Ru, and Pd0.5Ru0.5 NP with average diameter of ca. 10 nm. Pd, Ru, and Pd0.5Ru0.5 NPs were synthesized according to the procedure described in an earlier report. [9] K2[PdCl4] (Aldrich) and RuCl3·nH2O (Wako Chemicals) were dissolved in the deionized water. The resulting solution was slowly added to the triethylene glycol solution, where poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP, MW ≈ 40 000, Wako Chemicals) was dissolved, at 200 °C. After cooling down to the ambient temperature, the prepared nanoparticles were separated by the centrifugation. Pd, Ru, and Pd0.5Ru0.5 nanoparticles were supported on γ-Al2O3 (AKP-GO15, Sumitomo Chemical) by the methods shown in a previous report. [9] The loading of nanoparticles was set to 1 wt%. The γ-Al2O3 support was calcined at 800 °C for 5 h and added to an aqueous suspension containing each nanoparticle. The suspension was stirred for 12 h and heated to 60 °C under vacuum. The powders were then maintained at 120 °C for 8 h to remove water. The catalysts powders were pressed into pellets at 1.2 MPa for 5 min. The pellets were crushed and sieved to obtain grains with a diameter between 0.18-0.25 mm. 50 mg of the catalyst was physically mixed with 450 mg of SiC (Kishida Chemical) and loaded into a tubular quartz reactor (internal diameter = 7 mm) with quartz wool. CO/O2/N2 mixture with a space velocity of 480 L/(h·g-cat) was fed to the catalyst at ambient temperature and the catalyst was heated to pre-treatment temperature (150–180 °C) and kept for 0.5 h. Then, the catalyst temperature was decreased to reaction temperature (125–170 °C) and the reaction rate was measured with changing ratio of CO/O2. Effluent gas was collected, converted to CH4 in methanator, and analyzed by gas chromatography with a flame-ionized detector (GC-8 A, Shimadzu, Japan). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption of CO and O on Pd(111), Ru(0001), and Rh(111) We first analyzed the most stable adsorption states of CO and O on the monometallic systems. The calculated adsorption energies and equilibrium bond distances of CO and O adsorbed on the various sites of Pd(111), Rh(111), and Ru(0001) are listed in Table 2 . The adsorption energies for CO of 3-fold hcp and fcc sites on Pd(111) were close to each other (-1.99 and -1.95 eV). The bridge site of Pd(111) was 0.17 eV less stable than the 3-fold hcp site, and top Pd was the least stable with the adsorption energy of -1.39 eV. In the case of Ru(0001), top Ru was the most stable site for CO adsorption with -1.81 eV. Bridge and 3-fold sites were 0.11-0.19 eV less stable than the top site. 3-fold hcp on Rh(111) gave the most stable adsorption energy for CO, which is different from literature [40] showing top Rh as the most stable adsorption site. However, the difference of adsorption energies of top and hcp sites was only 0.01 eV and thus can be regarded reasonable by considering the accuracy of DFT. For all adsorption sites, the CO bonded to the metal by the carbon atom, perpendicular to the metal surface. The CO bond length in gas phase was 1.14 Å, which is close enough to the experimental value of 1.13 Å [33]. The bond length of adsorbed CO molecule on the surface was longer than CO in gas the phase by 0.02 to 0.06 Å. For all metal surfaces, we observed that the elongation of CO was more pronounced for 3-fold sites, followed by bridge and top sites. Our DFT calculations showed that O also prefers to adsorb on 3-fold fcc and hcp sites in Pd(111) and Ru(0001) surfaces, respectively. The bridge and top site adsorptions were not observed for O after optimization in Pd(111) surface, which agreed well with literature. [35,37] 3-fold hcp of Ru(0001) offered the most stable adsorption energy for O with -3.34 eV, and weaker -2.83 eV for 3-fold fcc site was obtained. The adsorption energies of these two sites were similar, and much larger than that for the top site in Rh(111) surface. 3.2 Adsorption of CO and O on Pd0.5Ru0.5 As described in the computational details, 24 unique high symmetry sites were available on Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy surfaces. Because the 20 different configurations were prepared as the Pd0.5Ru0.5 surface model, 480 adsorption energies were obtained and were plotted in Figure S3. The average values of top Pd, top Ru, bridge PdPd, bridge PdRu, bridge RuRu, and 3-fold among 20 configurations were plotted in this Fig. 2 . The comparison between the adsorption energy on Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy surfaces with the Pd and Rh were based on the average values. The difference of adsorption energy between all configurations is acceptable which is deemed sufficient to represent the whole data set as average adsorption energy, as had been practiced in Sue et al [42]. It was observed that the adsorption energies and preference sites of alloy were significantly different from the monometallic Pd and Ru. Compared to the calculated bond length of CO molecule in the gas phase, the elongations of CO bond length were observed for all the cases investigated, as observed in monometallic surfaces. It is interesting to note that the adsorption energy of CO on top of Pd became weaker while stronger adsorption energy was observed on top of Ru, as compared to monometallic Pd and Ru surfaces. The result obtained here was in conjunction with the IR spectra observed by experiment. As for other adsorption sites, bridge PdRu and RuRu and 3-fold Pd2Ru and PdRu2 sites were found as the stronger adsorption energies compared to Pd(111) and Ru(0001) with significant elongation of CO bond length. To understand the observed results, we calculated the partial DOS (PDOS) of surface atoms for Pd(111), Ru(0001) and Pd0.5Ru0.5(111) with configuration 1 (Figure S2) to see details of electronic structure of the surface alloy. The d-band of surface atoms was also calculated from the PDOS. The d-band centers of Pd(111) and Ru(0001) in relative to Fermi Energy were -1.92 and -2.16 eV, respectively. In the PdRu alloy system, the local Pd d-band center shifted down to -2.44 eV and conversely the Ru d-band center shifted upward to -1.99 eV. This could be attributed to the electron transfer from Pd to Ru, as discussed by Tang et al. [43] for PdCu nanoalloy. Therefore, a partially positive charge on the Pd decreased the ability to coordinate CO leading to a weaker CO adsorption energy. On the other hand, Ru strengthens the CO adsorption because of receiving charge from Pd. Similar initial adsorption sites as CO were tested for O on Pd0.5Ru0.5(111) surfaces. After the geometry optimization, the O atom was found to favor the 3-fold sites, as observed for Pd, Rh and Ru surfaces. Two types of 3-fold adsorption sites were PdRu2 and Pd2Ru sites. Comparing the energies on these two adsorption sites, the PdRu2 structure was the most stable for all configurations, followed by Pd2Ru site. The oxygen adsorption energies for 3-fold sites (RdRu2 and Pd2Ru) are listed in Table 3 . As observed in the experiment, [9] the Pd-Ru SSNP exhibits fcc and hcp structures because Pd and Ru have the fcc and hcp structures, respectively. To accommodate this observation, we also calculated the Pd0.5Ru0.5 surface models with hcp structure based on the (0001) surface orientation (Figure S4). We figured out that the hcp surface models show the same with that of fcc. The CO adsorption energy was weakened on top Pd site of the Pd0.5Ru0.5 surface compared to the Pd surface. Elongation of CO molecule was also observed in the same order; 3-fold, bridge, and top sites. Whereas, the O atom also preferred the 3-fold hollow sites of (0001) surfaces. These trends were resulted from the similarity of surface structure of fcc (111) and hcp (0001). (Figure S4 and Table S1). 3.3 Adsorption state of CO To understand the surface properties of the catalyst, we determined the state of the adsorbed CO molecules by means of Fourier transform IR spectroscopy. The diﬀ ;erence IR spectra measured after addition of CO to the Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Pd0.5Ru0.5/γ-Al2O3 at room temperature are shown in Fig. 3 . The IR spectra of the Pd0.5Ru0.5/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/γ-Al2O3 show peaks assignable to adsorbed CO at 1968 cm−1 and 1875 cm−1, respectively. There is a possibility that CO adsorbs on the surface of Pd and Ru with several orientations [44], thus it is difficult to determine the orientation of CO adsorbed on Pd0.5Ru0.5/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/γ-Al2O3. However, at least, we can conclude that CO, which adsorbs on Pd0.5Ru0.5 surface, has weaker binding energy compared to that of CO adsorbed on Pd surface. 3.4 CO oxidation kinetics We analyzed the reaction order, by measuring the reaction rate under various partial pressures of CO and O2. Due to the different temperature profiles of the conversions, the reaction temperature was optimized for each measurement. Note that activation energy has not been discussed here because the number of possible alloy configurations for the elements on the catalyst surface and its corresponding co-adsorbed species in this work is huge. It would be considerably time-consuming because for each of 22 surface configurations used in this study, it would require tens of transition state calculations. Due to these reasons, the reaction order for partial pressure of CO and O2 gas are selected to discuss the CO oxidation mechanism against the experimental observation and to propose the mechanism, as reported in preceding studies. [45,46] In Fig. 4 (a), the rate of reactions was estimated from five different partial pressures of CO in the range of 0.0013-0.0023 atm, by keeping the partial pressure of O2 at 0.0250 atm. The slope of the lines in the graph represents the reaction order value. As observed in Fig. 4(a), the reaction order for Pd/γ-Al2O3 was -1.0 while less negative value was obtained for Pd0.5Ru0.5 catalyst (-0.7). The negative-first-order with respect to CO on Pd/γ-Al2O3 was also observed in literature. [47] Although CO adsorption still dominates (-0.7 reaction order), it is less negative than Pd catalysts. Similarly, the reaction order of O2 was estimated from five different partial pressures of O2 in the range of 0.0250-0.0150 atm by keeping the partial pressure of CO at 0.0260 atm. Likewise, the linear relation was obtained, as shown in Fig. 4(b), giving the reaction order with respect to O2 as +1.0 for both catalysts. These experimental results were summarized in Table 4 . Here, we will discuss the CO oxidation mechanism based on the DFT calculation results. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) reaction between adsorbed CO and O atoms was first assumed here by referring the literature46]. According to the mechanism, both CO and O atoms were adsorbed on the surface to react subsequently. McClure et al. [48] described the reaction steps as: (2) O 2 g ↔ 2 O ads (3) C O g ↔ C O ads (4) O ads + C O ads → C O 2 g . If we assume the adsorption is sufficiently fast and the adsorption is in equilibrium, the surface coverage based on Langmuir’s adsorption is (5) θ CO = K CO P CO 1+ K CO P CO + K O P O 2 (6) θ O = K O P O 2 1+ K O P O 2 + K CO P CO where θCO and θO is the surface coverage of CO and O, respectively. P CO and P O 2 is the partial pressure in the gas phase for CO and O2, respectively. K CO and K O are the equilibrium constants for CO and O adsorption, respectively. The adsorption equilibrium constants are estimated as (7) K CO = exp − E ads , CO RT (8) K O = exp − E ads , O 2 RT where Eads is the adsorption energy for CO and O, R is the universal gas constant and T is the temperature, respectively. From the above, a rate expression, r, which is supposed to be proportional to the surface coverages,θ, and is given by equations (5) and (6), can be formulated as, (9) r = k r θ CO θ O where kr is the rate constant. Insertion of the appropriate surface coverage,θ, for CO and O2 gives the reaction rate in terms of partial pressure of the CO and O2, (10) r = k r K CO P CO K O P O 2 1 + K O P O 2 + K CO P CO 2 The above equation (10) applies to the homogeneous monometallic surface. The reaction on heterogeneous Pd0.5Ru0.5 surface can be considered in a similar way. If we consider that the CO adsorbed on Ru ontop site reacts with O adsorbed on PdRu2 fcc site, the reaction rate expression is represented as, (11) r P d 0.5 R u 0.5 = k r θ CO Ru θ O PdR u 2 and gives (12) r P d 0.5 R u 0.5 = k r K CO Ru P CO K O PdR u 2 P O 2 1 + K CO Ru P CO + K O Ru P O 2 1 + K CO PdR u 2 P CO + K O PdR u 2 P O 2 where K C O R u and K O R u are the equilibrium constant for CO and O adsorption on Ru; K C O P d R u 2 and K O P d R u 2 are the equilibrium constants for CO and O adsorption on Ru ontop and PdRu2 fcc site, respectively. The reaction rates on Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy based on equation (12) were plotted against the partial pressure of CO and O2 in Figures S5 (a) and (b). As for experimental investigation, the partial pressure of CO (O2) was varied while the partial pressure of O2 (CO) was kept constant. The partial pressure range used here was in between 0 atm to 1 × 10−8 atm. This partial pressure range was used in order to see a wider pressure dependency for CO and O, even though it was not considered in the experimental observation but still not differ much than the experimental conditions. The negative-first-order behavior of CO pressure dependence on Pd(111) was observed as displayed in Figure S5(a) throughout the tested partial pressure of CO. In the similar partial pressure range with experimental, which is consistent with the results obtained by experimental observation in this work as well as that in the literature [47]. As for Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy, the reaction order was experimentally observed to be -0.7 and this value may be found at 1.87 × 10-6 atm from the Figure S5(a). The less negative reaction order value for Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy was consistent with the weaker binding energy of CO on Pd0.5Ru0.5 (111) surfaces, compared to Pd(111) and indicates that the Pd0.5Ru0.5 shows better durability towards CO poisoning, as compared to Pd. On the other hand, in Figure S5(b), the +0.5 reaction order was calculated for both Pd(111) and Pd0.5Ru0.5(111) surfaces, instead of +1.0 observed by experimental, throughout the tested partial pressure. A half-order reaction is often observed for a heterogeneous catalytic reaction where a reactant adsorbs with dissociation requiring two surface-active sites [48]. This value is expected since dissociated oxygen adsorption were assumed in Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. In this assumption, O2 will dissociate first into two O atoms and being adsorbed on surface of catalyst before the reaction takes place based on Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. However, this value was not in agreement with the observation for the reaction order for partial pressure of O2 gas from experimental. Other mechanisms associated with CO oxidation activity on catalyst are Eley-Rideal (ER) and more recently trimolecular Eley-Rideal (TER). Both mechanisms assume that CO will directly interact with O2 in gas phase. ER and TER fail to explain the reaction order of CO even though the reaction order of O2 is in agreement with the observation for the reaction order for partial pressure of O2 gas from experimental (Figure S6). Then it may be suggested that a positive-first-order dependence in O2 gas observed in experimental work corresponds to a reaction of Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism controlled by O2 adsorption (13) O 2 g ↔ O 2 ads (14) C O g ↔ C O ads (15) O 2 a d s + C O a d s ↔ OOC O ads In this reaction, CO and O2 molecule were adsorbed on surface of catalyst, which results in formation of intermediate OOCO. This step is believed to be the rate-determine step for the all process. Then the reaction rate will be, (16) r = k r θ CO θ O 2 Supposed that the coverage, θ C O follows the Langmuir isotherm, (17a) θ CO = K CO P CO 1 + K CO P CO + K O 2 P O 2 (17b) θ O 2 = K O 2 P O 2 1 + K CO P CO + K O 2 P O 2 Then; (18) r = k r K CO P CO K O 2 P O 2 1 + K CO P CO + K O 2 P O 2 2 One again, the reaction rates on Pd0.5Ru0.5 alloy based on equation (18) were plotted against the partial pressure of CO and O2 in Figures S7(a) and (b). From these graphs, we can find the reaction order for both gas partial pressure. -0.7 reaction order of CO gas partial pressure may be found at 4.54 × 10−3 atm, whereas for O2 gas partial pressure, the pressure range from very small up to 10-4 atm will give the +1.0 reaction order. In this kinetics the first-order with respect to the gas phase pressure of molecular oxygen, and negative order with respect to the CO partial pressure, in agreement with the experimental finding. Thus, we believe that the LH mechanism with O2 adsorption is probable as the CO oxidation mechanism over PdRu catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have carried out a systematic study to understand the catalytic activity of the PdRu SSNPs towards CO adsorptions and oxidation activities. The enhanced catalytic activity of the PdRu SSNP could be satisfactorily explained by (i) the mixing Pd with Ru weakens CO adsorption energy on Pd sites; ii) the lower adsorption energy that is attributed to the electron transfer from Pd to Ru that altered the d-band center of alloy; (iii) the reaction order of CO became less negative (from -1.0 to -0.7) while the positive value (+1.0) was obtained for O, after Ru inclusion in the Pd alloy, as observed in both method. Meanwhile, the reaction order calculated assuming the LH mechanism with O2 adsorption are in good agreement with the experimental value. We believe this present study provide important insights into the electronic properties and the associated reaction mechanism that is essential in finding suitable alternative material for TWCs that desirable both economically and environmentally. coredata.dc:description: The oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) over PdRu solid solution nanoparticles was studied by the combined theoretical and experimental approaches. In this work, CO and O adsorptions on PdRu alloy surface models were theoretically investigated to understand the kinetics of CO oxidation reaction. It was found that CO adsorption on Pd atom in the PdRu alloy surfaces is weaker than on monometallic surfaces. From the experiment, reaction order of CO on the PdRu surface was observed to be smaller than that on Pd surface. While, the positive first order with respect to O2 obtained for both Pd and PdRu alloy surfaces. Catalytic reaction mechanism is discussed on the basis of both theoretical and experimental observations.
coredata.dc:title: Combined theoretical and experimental studies of CO oxidation on PdRu nanoalloys
